Nine variables were used to deﬁne the synthesis dimen- sions, and after three generations of optimization, conditions to achieve samples with BET surface area of 2045 m2/g was identiﬁed, which is very close to the theoretical limit of 2153 m2/g for HKUST-1. Following the GA approach, a RF model was trained to capture the chemical intuition involved in the synthesis of HKUST-1. With the nine synthesis variables as inputs, model training was per- formed to predict the resulting crystallinity and phase purity of the samples. The model impressively showed a MAE of 8% in cross-validation. The constructed RF model was then analyzed to study the relative importance of each variable used in deﬁning the synthesis conditions (Fig. 21b). Among the variables, amount of H2O and DMF solvents used for synthesis were revealed to have the biggest impact on the synthesis outcomes. The relative impor- tance of different variables was then used to construct the weighted chemical space of HKUST-1 (Fig. 21c). Results showed that the Euclidean distances between data points (each represent- ing a synthesis attempt) can change dramatically compared to the unweighted chemical space (Fig. 21a). Closer distance between two points indicate similarity of the given set of synthesis condi- tions. Hence, it is ideal to obtain the most diverse set of points from the weighted chemical space in screening and optimizing the synthesis conditions for HKUST-1. The successful capture of chemical intuition by the RF model was then demonstrated by considering the change of metal ions, from Cu(II) to Zn(II), to obtain Zn-HKUST-1. At ﬁrst, top ten synthesis conditions for Cu-HKUST-1 were blindly adopted for Zn-HKUST-1, where none of the attempts resulted in crystalline samples. Subsequently, diverse sampling was conducted to obtain 20 sets of conditions from the unweighted chemical space of Zn-HKUST-1. Unfortunately, none of these attempts resulted in successful synthesis of the MOF. Finally, to observe the validity of chemical intuition acquired by ML, diverse sampling of synthesis Fig. 21. Remarkably, two of the 20 sampled conditions resulted in the successful synthesis of Zn-HKUST-1. A closer look of the data distribution on the weighted chemical space of Zn-HKUST-1 (Fig. 21d) revealed that unweighted sampling exhibited in an uneven distribution, where several clusters of points were found. Conversely, data points sam- pled from the weighted chemical space showed a far more even distribution. This shows that accounting for the chemical intuition can dramatically increase the synthesis screening efﬁciency by pri- oritizing the most important variables. In these works, perhaps the most important aspect in applying ML is the availability of data pertaining to the numerous failed syn- thesis attempts. Almost always, researchers only report successful synthesis of materials in publications, and omit any information about the failed experiments that would have taken place along the way. However, it is important to recognize that both successes and failures must be present in a ML dataset for the resulting model to suitably identify the required synthesis conditions. As Moosavi et al. emphasizes, if synthetic research groups can collec- tively participate in the systematic reporting of their MOF synthe- sis attempts, enough data will be accumulated for better ML model training. In such a case, ML will be able to revolutionize MOF research by guiding the experimentalists along the most efﬁcient path for the successful, optimal synthesis of their target MOFs. 4. ML-assisted design of MOFs and other porous materials In the previous section, we summarized many of the important works focused on using ML to predict various material properties of MOFs. On the other hand, using ML (or deep learning) to gener- ate new MOF structures, and perhaps more importantly design user-desired MOFs via inverse design has yet to be extensively explored and pose much more of a signiﬁcant challenge. Broadly speaking, small drug molecules have been successfully designed using various generative models [100] due to their relatively sim- ple structures; but only a limited number of studies have been con- ducted on generating crystalline materials [73,154,155], and especially porous materials [94,156,157], due to their complex nat- ure (e.g. periodicity and larger number of atoms). Recently, Lee et al. [156] predicted the performance limit of methane gas storage in zeolites by using generative ANN models. Their idea was to predict the maximum adsorption capacity of a zeolites by measuring its properties by creating as many as possi- ble volumetric images called energy shape which can be one-to- one mapped to actual zeolite (Fig. 22). The energy shape is a three-dimensional grid data that contains interaction energy between methane and the zeolite. GCMC simulations can be con- ducted directly on energy shape because it contains the interac- tion energy between adsorbate and the zeolite. In order to create energy shapes similar to but more diverse than those obtained from actual zeolites, they developed generative model based on the generative adversarial network (GAN)[158] and named it energy shape GAN (ESGAN). They conﬁrmed that the adsorption properties (e.g. CH4 heat of adsorption and void frac- tion) of ESGAN-generated energy shapes have a similar distribu- tion to those of zeolite used in the dataset. In particular, it was shown that the maximum value of CH4 deliverable capacity deduced from the generated energy shapes has a value of 156.74 cm3/cm3, which is almost identical to the maximum deliv- erable capacity value of 159.41 cm3/cm3 of actual known zeolites. Even more interesting is that even if the maximum value of the deliverable capacity of training set zeolites was limited to 100 cm3/cm3, ESGAN still successfully generated energy shapes with the maximum deliverable capacity values close to that of the actual zeolites. This nicely demonstrates the ESGAN’s ability to generate diverse energy shapes for the entire class of materials in consideration. Fig. 22. (a) The unit cells of 4 zeolites (BEA, ABW, ACO, LTA) and their corresponding energy shapes. (b) Energy shapes that were successfully generated by ESGAN. Figures reproduced with permission from Ref. [156], Copyright 2019 Royal Society of Chemistry. 22 S. Chong et al. / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 423 (2020) 213487 The downside of the aforementioned ESGAN model is that it cannot generate actual material structures. To remedy this prob- lem, Kim et al. [157] developed another generative ML model named zeolite GAN (ZeoGAN) that can generate actual nanoporous zeolite structures. ZeoGAN is based on the ESGAN architecture, but unlike its predecessor, ZeoGAN now takes the material shape as an additional input (Fig. 23). The material shape is given in a three- dimensional grid that contains atomic positions smeared by Gaus- sian function. Material shape grid and energy shape grid was deﬁned to be present as different channels of the three- dimensional image, much like the RGB channels in image process- ing. Trained ZeoGAN was shown to successfully generate material shapes and energy shapes similar to that of the actual zeolites from the volumetric image data. In order to obtain the actual structures from these volumetric images, a post-processing algorithm that can construct zeolite structures from the generated material shapes was developed. Additionally, using the fact that the adsorp- tion properties can be calculated directly from the energy shape, they added a penalty function to the loss function of the ZeoGAN network to generate zeolites with the user-desired range of prop- erties. From their ﬁnal ZeoGAN model with penalty-added loss function, they demonstrated that zeolites exhibiting methane heat of adsorption in a narrow, user-desired range of 18–22 kJ/mol can be exclusively generated. In another work, Zhang et al. [159] developed a new ML approach that can discover MOFs with user-desired properties by generating an optimal organic linker for a given metal node and topology net. On the provided set of metal node, topology and tar- get application (property), Monte Carlo tree search (MCTS) as implemented in ChemTS [160] is performed to generate an organic linker that optimizes the target property. Here, organic linkers are represented in the Simpliﬁed Molecular Input Line Entry (SMILES) format [97]. In their MCTS formulation, the value of each node in the tree would be a character allowed for SMILES. This means that moving along a speciﬁc ‘‘branch” of the search tree would result in a full SMILES description of an organic linker. Recurrent neural net- work (RNN) is used to predict the value of the child node from the values of parent nodes. Then, the reward values for MCTS are cal- culated using GCMC simulations. In testing their approach, they applied this method to ten metal nodes and topology combinations of existing MOFs. They found that their approach can successfully design new MOFs with performance higher than that of existing MOFs for methane-storage applications and carbon-capture applications. More recently, Yao et al. [94] successfully demonstrated a ML- based MOF generation scheme by devising and constructing supramolecular variational autoencoder (SmVAE) (Fig. 24). In a variational autoencoder (VAE), two separate neural networks are constructed for unsupervised learning: one acts as an encoder that maps an input into the latent space, and another functions as a decoder that decodes a point from the latent space into the original format. In SmVAE, RFcode was used as the MOF representation of choice, which in turn enabled for the facile deconstruction and reconstruction of MOFs. Note that this representation scheme allows for the edges, vertices, and topologies to be treated individ- ually. As such, the authors were able to focus their considerations to 14 metal and 47 organic vertices, and 152 topologies. As for the edges, ~300,000 augmented edges dataset was generated and used for model training. To validate the successful construction of a latent MOF space using SmVAE, a known MOF, NU-1104, was iden- tiﬁed within the latent space. Then, neighboring points with vary- ing distances were surveyed to conﬁrm that structural similarity of sampled MOFs is inversely proportional to their distance from the reference point. They also performed an interpolation between two distinct MOFs, NU-1104 and NU-1000, within the latent space, and observed a smooth transition from the cubic MOF to hexagonal MOF in the intermediate materials. Ultimately, it is desirable to utilize SmVAE for the ‘‘inverse design” of MOFs, where frameworks with the best performance for target applications can be efﬁciently identiﬁed and generated. To do so, SmVAE must be trained to also simultaneously predict material performance as well as deconstruct and reconstruct mate- rials, and hence loss function for the prediction of target properties should be additionally deﬁned. In this work, CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 separation were chosen as applications of interest. Then, additional material properties (i.e. geometrical descriptors) and selective CO2 capture performance data of randomly chosen 40,000 MOFs were newly incorporated during ML training. To screen through the latent space of jointly trained SmVAE, Gaussian Process (GP) model was developed. Remarkably, their compound model was able to identify and generate MOFs with superb separation performances. The best generated MOF (GMOF-9) exhibited CO2/CH4 selectivity of 16 while capturing 7.55 mol/kg of CO2, and CO2/N2 selectivity of 24.6 while capturing 2.8 mol/kg of CO2. These performances are comparable to that of the best adsorbent materials known to date. Fig. 23. Conclusion and outlook Recently, machine learning (ML) has emerged as an important tool that can reveal correlations and patterns that are not easy to discern using other conventional techniques. As seen in the research works that appear in this review, it is obvious ML meth- ods have had a great impact on MOF research as well. While signif- icant progress has been made thus far, application of ML methods to MOFs has only just begun. We anticipate there to be a signiﬁcant increase in the number of works devoted to improving and expanding the utilization of ML techniques to develop and to pre- dict material properties of MOFs in the nearby future. For the remainder of this section, we share our own perspectives on the outlook of ML utilization in various ﬁelds of MOF research. Many descriptors have already been developed and used for the prediction of MOF properties using ML. These descriptors range from pore volume, surface area, and building block counts, to aver- age Boltzmann factors and energy histograms. Depending on the property of interest, the most effective set of descriptors for ML can vary signiﬁcantly, and as such, it would be important to con- tinue the development of various MOF descriptors for ML, which can then be utilized for different scenarios and further enhance the ML model performances. Descriptors that are more speciﬁc to MOFs could potentially improve the resulting ML model perfor- mance, and one possibility would be descriptors that consider indi- vidual building blocks of MOFs as ‘‘superatoms”. This would enable the highly efﬁcient and modular description of material’s structure that is unique to MOFs. Such descriptors would then be used to reveal the performance trends of MOFs as determined and distin- guished by the actual building blocks used in MOF synthesis. They can also be utilized in conjunction with currently employed atomic-level descriptors for a hierarchical, in-depth consideration of a given MOF. Perhaps due to the relative ease of performance prediction via computational methods and abundance of data from such simula- tions, many of the works presented here have performed ML from pre-existing simulation data. A new, propitious direction for ML utilization in MOF research would be its direct involvement in the molecular simulations of MOFs. Recently, construction of neu- ral networks for the description of potential energy surfaces of var- ious chemical entities has been successfully demonstrated [161,162]. These ‘‘neural network potentials” are impressive in that their accuracy is comparable to DFT methods, yet their speed is remarkably faster than DFT calculations. Similar methods are being developed for MOFs as well, as seen in several recent publi- cations [163,164]. Note that the conventional molecular simula- tions (e.g. MD and GCMC) involve generalized force ﬁelds that are often much less accurate than DFT calculations. Hence, the use of ML-based neural network potentials will greatly enhance the accuracy of computational methods and better facilitate the prediction of MOF performance. A clearly recognizable trend in the research works presented in this review is that most of them have performed supervised learn- ing, where a fully labeled dataset is provided for classiﬁcation and regression tasks. In the future, we expect other modes of ML, such as semi-supervised learning or unsupervised learning, to be more actively incorporated into MOF research. In semi-supervised learn- ing, ML model itself would predict and determine the labels for a large set of unlabeled data by learning from a small subset of labeled data. Such semi-supervised learning would be immensely beneﬁcial in considering a large number of MOFs, especially for properties (e.g. catalytic activity, electrical conductivity) that require direct experimental efforts or expensive DFT-level calcula- tions. With unsupervised learning, where no labels are given in the data provided, ML models could uncover previously unknown trends in MOFs. This would lead to improved understanding of the intrinsic properties of these materials. We also anticipate gen- erative models to play a much more direct and signiﬁcant role in the design of new MOFs. Here, we note that the purely atomic approach previously seen in zeolites and other inorganic materials would be highly inefﬁcient for MOF generation. Instead, a genera- tive ML architecture specialized for MOFs should be developed, Fig. 24. Schematics of supramolecular variational autoencoder (SmVAE) that can be used for the latent space consideration of MOFs and other reticular frameworks. A MOF can be encoded into an RFcode for the mapping of its latent material space. Conversely, an RFcode can be decoded to obtain the respective framework. Figure reproduced from Ref. [94]. 24 S. Chong et al. / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 423 (2020) 213487 which takes full advantage of their modularity. An example of such architecture would be comprised of the following: generative mod- els for MOF building blocks (i.e. organic linkers and metal clusters), separate generative model for topologies, then a constructor which would assemble a new MOF from the generated components. Lastly, we envisage that ML methods will be used to effectively bridge the gap between computational and experimental efforts in MOF research. While computational works have made monumen- tal contributions to the research ﬁeld, they often lack a thorough consideration of experimental synthesis. This is especially the case for computational design of new MOFs. Numerous hypothetical MOFs can be generated for various applications, yet their synthe- sizability is not sufﬁciently addressed. Luckily, as seen in few of the works presented in this review, ML models can effectively guide researchers toward successful synthesis conditions if trained with relevant data. We believe such models can then be applied to discern whether or not a proposed hypothetical MOF is experimen- tally synthesizable. It then becomes important to continue the gathering of experimental data from existing publications. Since such data are limited in that they often only provide one set of suc- cessful synthesis conditions, it would also be tremendously helpful to establish an online repository where experimental data from both successful and failed synthesis attempts can be freely reported (similar to one proposed by Moosavi et al.). With such a database, more ML-based studies could be performed to directly consider the synthetic feasibility, scalability, long-term stability, etc. of MOFs. While we have provided several prospective research directions hitherto, we are conﬁdent there exist many other opportunities for ML to be incorporated into MOF research. We look forward to observing new ways in which the conventional computational screening methods will be integrated with ML, and also how the emergent developments in the ML ﬁeld would be incorporated to further enhance design and development of new MOFs.
